   CT torso:
   1. No CT evidence of disseminated fungal infection. Large amount of
   ascites
   within the abdomen and pelvis. Diffuse bowel wall thickening which may
   be
   related to third spacing. However, given history of C. difficile
   infection,
   bowel wall thickening of the colon could also represent colitis.
   2. Continued hypoenhancement of the kidneys bilaterally, unchanged from
   [**4-5**], [**2168**], again concerning for cortical necrosis.
   3. Peripheral nonenhancement of the spleen, unchanged, consistent with
   splenic infarction.
   4. Central venous line ends within the upper inferior vena cava,
   unchanged.
   5. Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.
   6. Diffuse anasarca, worsening.
   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis transferred back to the MICU with altered mental
   status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Lines re-changed yesterday [**4-16**]. Patient
   had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d. If
   seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess formation 3 week course would
   have likely been inadequate. Left thigh fluid collection previously
   drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from thigh NGTD.  She had no more
   fevers overnight but  is still very dependent on pressors. WBC still
   elevated at 23 ( has been ranging  22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage
   negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.  She has clean eye exam
   with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all
   old lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - ID following, discuss regarding taking off antibacterials
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant pseudomonas)
   but talk to ID regarding whether needs these, IV vanco and PO vanco
   given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Mental
   status improved today.
   - Trial SBT again today for 30-60min to see whether can trial
   extubation today
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration.
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Still intubated for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low dose Levophed but unable
   to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

   2. Continued hypoenhancement of the kidneys bilaterally, unchanged from
   [**4-5**], [**2168**], again concerning for cortical necrosis.
   3. Peripheral nonenhancement of the spleen, unchanged, consistent with
   splenic infarction.
   4. Central venous line ends within the upper inferior vena cava,
   unchanged.
   5. Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.
   6. Diffuse anasarca, worsening.
   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis transferred back to the MICU with altered mental
   status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Lines re-changed yesterday [**4-16**]. Patient
   had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d. If
   seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess formation 3 week course would
   have likely been inadequate. Left thigh fluid collection previously
   drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from thigh NGTD.  She had no more
   fevers overnight but  is still very dependent on pressors. WBC still
   elevated at 23 ( has been ranging  22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage
   negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.  She has clean eye exam
   with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all
   old lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - ID following, discuss regarding taking off antibacterials
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant pseudomonas)
   but talk to ID regarding whether needs these, IV vanco and PO vanco
   given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Mental
   status improved today.
   - Trial SBT again today for 30-60min to see whether can trial
   extubation today
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration.
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Still intubated for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low dose Levophed but unable
   to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of sepsis, C. difficile infection, and multiple abdominal infections, who is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. She has developed candidemia, which is likely line-related, and is being treated with micafungin and ambisome. The patient's mental status has improved, but she remains intubated for airway protection.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8F, blood pressure of 112/49 mmHg, heart rate of 68 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Her respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count of 23.8 K/uL, with a normal differential count. Her liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 34 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 164 IU/L. Her kidney function tests show an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 22.5 mL/min.

The patient's radiological studies show no evidence of disseminated fungal infection, but do show diffuse bowel wall thickening, which may be related to third spacing or colitis. The patient's CT scan also shows hypoenhancement of the kidneys bilaterally, consistent with cortical necrosis.

The patient's medical complications include candidemia, sepsis, hypoxia, altered mental status, hypotension, and portal venous and RIJ clots. She is being treated with antibiotics, antifungals, and supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and fluids.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's candidemia may progress to a disseminated fungal infection, which can lead to severe illness and death.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ failure and death.
3. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and death.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to confusion, disorientation, and difficulty with airway protection.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to organ failure and death.
6. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient's portal venous and RIJ clots may worsen, leading to bleeding and organ failure.
7. C. difficile infection: The patient's C. difficile infection may worsen, leading to severe colitis and death.
8. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver dysfunction may worsen, leading to liver failure and death.
9. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's kidney dysfunction may worsen, leading to kidney failure and death.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve her outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of sepsis, C. diff, and multiple abdominal infections, currently admitted to the ICU. The patient is experiencing altered mental status and has a history of prior yeast infections.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 68 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 112/49 mmHg. She is receiving respiratory support through a ventilator and has a SpO2 of 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil count, and C-reactive protein, indicating ongoing inflammation. Her blood cultures have grown yeast, but the species has not yet been identified. Her abdominal fluid cultures are pending, and her pleural fluid and ascites cultures are pending as well.

The patient's medications include vancomycin, micafungin, and heparin, among others. She has a central venous catheter and an arterial line in place. Her nutritional needs are being met through total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and tube feeds.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, particularly in the context of her altered mental status and history of prior yeast infections.
2. Infection-related complications, such as abscess formation or disseminated infection.
3. Gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or bleeding, given her history of multiple abdominal infections.
4. Respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or respiratory failure, given her need for mechanical ventilation.
5. Cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure, given her history of sepsis and the use of vasopressors.
6. Neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalopathy, given her altered mental status and history of prior yeast infections.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and ongoing infections, it is essential to continue monitoring her closely and adjusting her treatment plan as necessary to prevent or manage potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the MICU with altered
   mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Her PICC  & HD now pulled out and new IJ
   placed [**4-14**]. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate. Left thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from
   thigh NGTD.  She had no more fevers overnight but  is still very
   dependent on pressors. WBC still elevated at 23 ( has been ranging
   22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage negative for SBP and no fungus
   growing to date.  She has clean eye exam with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome for now pending speciation
   and sensitivities.
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited for fresh access / all old
   lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u final CT torso final read
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean  sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Now had 2L
   taken off abd yesterday and pleural effusions better.
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration. On AC ventilation
   - Would pursue additional volume removal as BP tolerates, may need CVVH
   - Continue on AC until done with procedures, then can trial on PS
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Normal cortisol levels this morning. CVP 12 now.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   - Trend lactate
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed yesterday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin in anticipation of new line
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, hepatitis B, and autoimmune cholangiopathy. She was recently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with altered mental status, candidemia, and sepsis. She has a history of C. diff colitis and has undergone debridement of an abdominal abscess. She is currently receiving treatment for candidemia with micafungin and ambisome, and has had blood cultures positive for Candida.

The patient's current condition is critical, with septic physiology requiring pressors intermittently. She is intubated for airway protection and has been experiencing hypoxia, hypotension, and altered mental status. She has a history of seizures and is being treated for possible seizure activity.

The patient's abdominal wound is being managed with a wound vacuum, and she has a history of portal venous and right internal jugular (RIJ) clots. She is being treated for candidemia and sepsis, and is receiving antifungal therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Candidemia: The patient's candidemia is a significant concern, and she may require additional treatment with antifungal agents.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be related to her sepsis, candidemia, or other underlying conditions, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
4. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may be related to her sepsis, candidemia, or other underlying conditions, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be related to her sepsis, candidemia, or other underlying conditions, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Abdominal Wound Complications: The patient's abdominal wound may be at risk for further complications, such as infection or dehiscence.
7. Portal Venous and RIJ Clots: The patient's portal venous and RIJ clots may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.
8. Hepatitis B: The patient's hepatitis B may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.
9. Autoimmune Cholangiopathy: The patient's autoimmune cholangiopathy may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.
10. End-Stage Renal Disease: The patient's end-stage renal disease may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antifungal therapy for candidemia.
2. Continue treatment for sepsis, including antibiotics and pressors as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's mental status closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's oxygenation and ventilation closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's abdominal wound closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's portal venous and RIJ clots closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's hepatitis B closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
9. Monitor the patient's autoimmune cholangiopathy closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.
10. Monitor the patient's end-stage renal disease closely and consider further evaluation and treatment as needed.

   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), and a recent prolonged hospitalization for a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube-related abdominal abscess. She was transferred back to the intensive care unit (ICU) with altered mental status, candidemia, and sepsis. The patient has a history of C. glabrata line infection, which was treated with fluconazole. She has also had a left thigh fluid collection that was drained and showed no growth of fungus.

Current Status:

* The patient is intubated for airway protection and is receiving mechanical ventilation.
* She has a central venous catheter (CVC) in place and is receiving pressors to maintain blood pressure.
* She has a left IJ in place and is receiving heparin to prevent thrombosis.
* She has a history of C. difficile colitis and is currently receiving treatment for candidemia.
* She has a left thigh fluid collection that is being monitored for signs of infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to her underlying infections and immunosuppressed state.
* Candidemia: The patient has a high risk of developing candidemia due to her central venous catheter and history of C. glabrata line infection.
* Line-related infections: The patient has a high risk of developing line-related infections due to her central venous catheter and history of CVC-related infections.
* Thrombosis: The patient has a high risk of developing thrombosis due to her central venous catheter and history of CVC-related thrombosis.
* Organ failure: The patient has a high risk of developing organ failure due to her underlying infections and immunosuppressed state.
* Seizures: The patient has a high risk of developing seizures due to her altered mental status and history of meropenem treatment.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has a high risk of developing respiratory failure due to her underlying infections and immunosuppressed state.

Recommendations:

* Continue treatment for candidemia and sepsis.
* Monitor the patient's central venous catheter for signs of infection and thrombosis.
* Consider removing the central venous catheter and placing a new one if necessary.
* Monitor the patient's left thigh fluid collection for signs of infection and consider draining it if necessary.
* Consider using antifungal therapy to prevent fungal infections.
* Monitor the patient's liver function and consider using antiviral therapy if necessary.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and consider using dialysis if necessary.
* Consider using vasopressors to maintain blood pressure and consider using inotropes to improve cardiac function.
* Monitor the patient's mental status and consider using sedation to reduce anxiety and agitation.

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of ESRD on HD, HBV, and autoimmune cholangiopathy, who was recently diagnosed with candidemia and C. diff colitis. She was transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status, candidemia, and sepsis. The patient has been treated with micafungin, amikacin, cefepime, and vancomycin, and has had multiple blood cultures and imaging studies performed.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Candidemia: The patient has a high risk of developing candidemia due to her recent use of TPN and her underlying condition of ESRD.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to her candidemia and C. diff colitis.
3. Line-related infections: The patient has had multiple lines placed, including a PICC, HD, and IJ, which may be at risk of becoming infected.
4. Organ failure: The patient has underlying kidney and liver disease, which may be exacerbated by her current condition.
5. Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status and is at risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
6. Respiratory complications: The patient has been intubated and is at risk of developing respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia.
7. Abdominal complications: The patient has an abdominal wound and is at risk of developing abdominal complications, such as abscesses or perforation.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has hypertension and is at risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as cardiogenic shock.

Plan:

1. Continue treatment for candidemia and C. diff colitis with micafungin, amikacin, cefepime, and vancomycin.
2. Monitor the patient's condition closely for signs of sepsis, line-related infections, organ failure, neurological complications, respiratory complications, abdominal complications, and cardiovascular complications.
3. Consider removing the left IJ line due to positive cultures.
4. Consider placing a new HD line or femoral line.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Consider performing a formal eye exam and ophthalmology consult to rule out any eye-related complications.
7. Continue to follow up with the patient's liver function tests and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Consider performing a neurocognitive evaluation to assess the patient's cognitive function.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary.
10. Consider performing a CT scan of the thorax to rule out any pulmonary complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, HBV, and a recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess. She was transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status and was found to have candidemia. The patient has a history of C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole for 23 days. She is currently receiving micafungin and has had multiple blood cultures positive for Candida.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Candidemia: The patient's candidemia is likely related to her recent hospitalization and prolonged use of central lines. She may require ongoing antifungal therapy and close monitoring for potential complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology requires ongoing treatment with antibiotics and close monitoring for signs of organ dysfunction.
3. Leukocytosis and Fever: The patient's leukocytosis and fever are likely related to her disseminated fungal infection. She may require ongoing antifungal therapy and close monitoring for signs of infection.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be related to her sepsis, candidemia, or other underlying medical conditions. She requires ongoing close monitoring and treatment of any underlying infections or medical conditions.
5. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is likely related to her sepsis and altered mental status. She may require ongoing oxygen therapy and close monitoring for signs of respiratory failure.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely related to her sepsis and candidemia. She may require ongoing treatment with vasopressors and close monitoring for signs of organ dysfunction.
7. Abdominal Wound: The patient's abdominal wound is at risk for infection and may require ongoing close monitoring and treatment with antibiotics.
8. Portal Venous and RIJ Clots: The patient's portal venous and RIJ clots may require ongoing anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring for signs of bleeding or thrombosis.
9. HepB, Autoimmune Cholangiopathy: The patient's HepB and autoimmune cholangiopathy may require ongoing treatment with antiviral therapy and close monitoring for signs of liver dysfunction.
10. ESRD on HD: The patient's ESRD on HD requires ongoing close monitoring and treatment with dialysis, as well as management of her underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antifungal therapy with micafungin and monitor for signs of response.
2. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and monitor for signs of response.
3. Monitor for signs of organ dysfunction and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Continue close monitoring of the patient's mental status and adjust treatment accordingly.
5. Continue oxygen therapy and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
6. Continue treatment with vasopressors and monitor for signs of organ dysfunction.
7. Monitor the patient's abdominal wound and adjust treatment accordingly.
8. Monitor the patient's portal venous and RIJ clots and adjust treatment accordingly.
9. Continue antiviral therapy for HepB and autoimmune cholangiopathy and monitor for signs of liver dysfunction.
10. Continue close monitoring of the patient's ESRD on HD and adjust treatment accordingly.

   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u final CT torso final read
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan
   - daily blood cultures, f/u pending micro from ascites & pleural tap as
   well
   - f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBC slight drop to 22 today, fevers
   continued to 101F overnight. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  Now has left
   IJs in place still.
   - trending fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - formal eye exam/ophthalmology consult as above
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C. diff diagnosis
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean  sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Now had 2L
   taken off abd yesterday and pleural effusions better.
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration. On AC ventilation
   - Would pursue additional volume removal as BP tolerates, may need CVVH
   - Continue on AC until done with procedures, then can trial on PS
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Normal cortisol levels this morning. CVP 12 now.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   - Trend lactate
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed yesterday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin in anticipation of new line
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B, and autoimmune cholangiopathy. She was recently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with altered mental status, fevers, and leukocytosis. The patient has a history of abdominal abscesses, candidemia, and C. difficile colitis.

The patient's current condition is critical, with septic physiology requiring pressors intermittently. She has been intubated for airway protection and is being treated for candidemia and C. difficile infection. The patient's abdominal wound is being managed with a wound vacuum, and she has portal venous and right internal jugular (RIJ) clots.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 22.2, with a slight drop from 26.9 earlier. Her hemoglobin is 26.7 g/dL, and her platelet count is 84,000. Her liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 164 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 10.1 IU/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology requires ongoing treatment and close monitoring.
2. Candidemia: The patient's candidemia is being treated with micafungin, and she will need to continue to receive antifungal therapy until the infection is cleared.
3. C. difficile infection: The patient's C. difficile infection is being treated with vancomycin, and she will need to continue to receive antibiotics until the infection is cleared.
4. Abdominal wound infection: The patient's abdominal wound is at risk for infection, and she will need to continue to receive wound care and antibiotics to prevent infection.
5. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient's portal venous and RIJ clots are a risk for thrombotic events and will need to be closely monitored.
6. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is being managed with oxygen therapy, and she will need to continue to receive oxygen to maintain adequate oxygenation.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is being managed with pressors, and she will need to continue to receive pressors to maintain adequate blood pressure.
8. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is being monitored, and she will need to continue to receive antibiotics to treat the underlying infection.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia is being monitored, and she will need to continue to receive blood transfusions as needed to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's septic physiology and adjust treatment as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's candidemia and C. difficile infection with antifungal and antibiotic therapy, respectively.
3. Continue to manage the patient's abdominal wound with wound care and antibiotics.
4. Monitor the patient's portal venous and RIJ clots for signs of thrombotic events.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypoxia with oxygen therapy.
6. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with pressors.
7. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust treatment as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust treatment as needed.
9. Consider consultation with infectious disease and nephrology specialists to optimize treatment and management.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is a 48-year-old male with ESRD and HBV cirrhosis, who has been experiencing a prolonged course after a recent complicated abdominal wound and polymicrobial bacteremia. He has developed fungemia and is currently being treated with micafungin and ambisome per ID recommendations.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C (98.8F), heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 137/63 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and liver enzymes, with a creatinine level of 3.2 mg/dL. His blood cultures are pending, and his peritoneal fluid and pleural fluid cultures are negative for C. difficile and other pathogens.

The patient's medical conditions include sepsis, respiratory failure, Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) infection, altered mental status, and renal insufficiency. He is receiving treatment for these conditions, including antibiotics, antifungals, and vasopressors.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old male with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) and Hepatitis B cirrhosis, who has had a prolonged course after recent complications from an abdominal wound and polymicrobial bacteremia. He is currently being treated for fungemia, likely caused by Candida albicans.

The patient is being managed in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for multiple complications, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient is likely experiencing sepsis due to the fungemia, and all lines have been changed recently. The ID team has started him on micafungin and ambisome, and will tailor the regimen as needed.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is overventilating on PSV 12/5 and is requiring a small amount of pressors. A SBT was performed this morning, and if it passes, the plan is to extubate him today.
3. Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection: The patient is being treated with vancomycin and metronidazole, and will likely require a prolonged course of treatment.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has cleared quickly, and he is following commands and nodding appropriately. A head CT was unremarkable, and an EEG showed diffuse slowing, likely due to toxic metabolic causes.
5. Renal issues: The patient is currently on hemodialysis (HD) holiday, and there is no clear indication for RRT at this time, although volume management will become an issue eventually.
6. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient has completed a steroid taper.
7. FEN (Fenestrated Endarterectomy): The patient is off TPN and TF is being held for possible extubation.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued sepsis and fungemia, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Respiratory failure, which could worsen if the patient is not adequately ventilated.
* C. diff infection, which could lead to diarrhea, abdominal pain, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Renal failure, which could require dialysis and potentially impact other organ systems.
* Autoimmune cholangiopathy, which could lead to further liver damage and potentially life-threatening complications.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: Peptamen 1.5 at 25 mL/hour
* Glycemic control: Regular insulin sliding scale
* Lines: Multi-lumen and arterial line
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Monitoring: Regular monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of his multiple complications to prevent further deterioration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, hypotension, chronic renal failure, and acute respiratory failure. The patient has undergone invasive ventilation and has been successfully extubated. They are currently on micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.3C (97.4F)
* Heart rate: 67 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 110/49 mmHg (69/44 mmHg - 151/63 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 27 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 27.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 6.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 415 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 116 mg/dL
* Sodium: 136 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mEq/L
* Chloride: 102 mEq/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.9 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the lack of assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, and other systems.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to more severe respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), requiring more aggressive respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications, such as septic shock.
3. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure may progress to acute kidney injury (AKI) or require dialysis, which can be challenging to manage in the ICU setting.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen, leading to organ hypoperfusion and potentially life-threatening complications, such as septic shock.
5. Infection: The patient's chronic kidney disease and acute respiratory failure may increase their risk of developing infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's chronic kidney disease and acute respiratory failure may lead to malnutrition, which can exacerbate their underlying conditions.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance may become compromised, leading to fluid overload and potentially life-threatening complications, such as pulmonary edema.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, close monitoring and aggressive management of their underlying conditions are necessary to prevent potential complications and improve their outcome.

   Patient
s abx narrowed yesterday to remain only on micafungin, and

   fever
 other site cultures have been negative (pleural fluid, left
   thigh fluid collection, peritoneal tap). Other site of seeding could be
   her valve with plan for TEE this week.
   .

   - Continue micafungin (restarted [**4-14**]) and cdiff tx with PO vanc

   - plan for TEE tomorrow
 call TEE fellow to confirm today
   .

   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. No more fevers, but WBC
   trending upwards. Other sites to evaluate include abdominal wound and

   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Plan for temp line placement and CVVH/HD today

   - Nutrition:  Dophoff placement for now vs re-evaluate ability to take

   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues

   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia readmitted with C.difficile colitis and found
   to have new candidemia with [**Female First Name (un) **] albicans.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   - Patient with positive BCx [**4-11**], [**4-13**], [**4-14**] with [**Female First Name (un) **] albicans
   likely in setting of TPN while off micafungin on floor. new A-line and
   right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all old lines
   removed
   Patient
s abx narrowed yesterday to remain only on micafungin, and
   cdiff coverage (PO vanc/flagyl). WBC continues to trend upwards without
   fever
 other site cultures have been negative (pleural fluid, left
   thigh fluid collection, peritoneal tap). Other site of seeding could be
   her valve with plan for TEE this week.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs regarding send out fungal sensitivities
   - Continue micafungin (restarted [**4-14**]) and cdiff tx with PO vanc
   (day#1=[**4-1**]) and flagyl (day #1=[**4-5**])
   - f/u cultures
   - holding all TPN for now
   - plan for TEE tomorrow
 call TEE fellow to confirm today
   .
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. No more fevers, but WBC
   trending upwards. Other sites to evaluate include abdominal wound and
   heart valves. Still septic physiology requiring low dose pressors.
   - ID following -
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - TEE to r/o vegetations
   - will hold off on repeat IR drainage of thigh fluid collections
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt respiratory
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, now on nasal cannula and doing
   well at 2L .  Initial SOB may have been fluid related or related to
   altered mental status. Less likely PE or aspiration.  Mental status
   improved today.
   - s/p extubation and doing well on NC at 2L , wean as tolerates
   - d/c Fentanyl today to limit sedation  ( Tylenol PRN)
   - favor additional volume removal, will get CVVH today.
   .
   # Altered mental status: Extubated yesterday and maintaining airway
   since. Mental status improved, but patient still lethargic with low
   energy. No evidence of seizures s/p extubation. Would be careful with
   narcotic medications as could have played role in lathergy/transfer
   back to MICU. Also may have element of uremia and hepatic related
   encephalopathy.
   -  continue to hold narcotics for now
   - getting CVVH , will help uremia effects
   -  treating infections as above
   - start lactulose today, follow up liver recs
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] septic etiology. She appears
   intravascularly volume overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low
   dose Levophed but unable to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed
   - monitor closely in setting of upcoming dialysis / CVVH today
   - Treating infection as above
   # ESRD on HD:
   Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Plan for CVVH/HD today with
   placement of temp HD catheter today. Heparin on hold this AM in
   preparation
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Plan for temp line placement and CVVH/HD today
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   Nutrition will be issue for the patient. Had abdominal infection s/p
   PEG placement, now with candidemia likely in setting of TPN.
   - Nutrition:  Dophoff placement for now vs re-evaluate ability to take
   POs (as will likely will not be enough intake & very  poor gag reflex
   now)
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac in place
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
 holding for AM for HD catheter placement but will
   resume after procedure later today
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI until better
   intake w/Dobhoff feeds
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: feeds with Dobhoff once placed
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

   pneumoboots

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Candidemia/Sepsis: The patient has a positive BCx culture with Candida albicans, which can lead to disseminated fungal infection, sepsis, and organ failure.
2. Leukocytosis and Fever: The patient's WBC count is trending upwards, which may indicate ongoing sepsis or infection. The patient's fever has resolved, but the underlying cause needs to be addressed.
3. Hypoxia: The patient was intubated for airway protection, and while oxygenation has improved, the patient may still be at risk for respiratory failure.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved, but they are still lethargic with low energy. The patient's altered mental status may be related to uremia, hepatic encephalopathy, or other underlying conditions.
5. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is unstable, and they require low-dose pressors. The patient may be at risk for organ failure if their blood pressure is not adequately managed.
6. ESRD on HD: The patient's kidney function is impaired, and they require hemodialysis. The patient's blood pressure and fluid status need to be closely monitored.
7. Hepatitis B: The patient has a history of hepatitis B, and their liver function needs to be closely monitored.
8. Autoimmune Cholangiopathy: The patient has a history of autoimmune cholangiopathy, and their liver function needs to be closely monitored.
9. Abdominal Wound: The patient has an abdominal wound that requires ongoing care and monitoring for infection and dehiscence.
10. Portal Venous and RIJ Clots: The patient has portal venous and RIJ clots that require anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued antifungal therapy with micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vanc and flagyl.
2. Close monitoring of the patient's WBC count and fever.
3. Continued pressor support to manage the patient's blood pressure.
4. Hemodialysis and CVVH to manage the patient's kidney function.
5. Ongoing management of the patient's abdominal wound.
6. Close monitoring of the patient's liver function and autoimmune cholangiopathy.
7. Anticoagulation therapy for portal venous and RIJ clots.
8. Nutrition management with Dobhoff feeds and insulin therapy for diabetes.

The patient's care requires close monitoring and coordination between the ICU team, ID specialist, and other medical professionals to address the patient's complex medical needs.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement. She has a history of C. difficile colitis and was readmitted with new candidemia with Candida albicans.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* She is extubated and on nasal cannula oxygen at 2L.
* She has a central venous catheter (CVC) and a temporary HD line to be placed today.
* She is receiving micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
* Her WBC count is trending upwards without fever.
* She has a history of C. difficile colitis and candidemia.
* She has a central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) and is at risk for further seeding of Candida albicans.
* She has a history of PEG placement and abdominal abscess requiring debridement.
* She has a history of TPN and is currently on hold.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Disseminated fungal infection: Given the patient's history of candidemia and CLABSI, there is a risk of disseminated fungal infection, which can lead to septic shock and organ failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's WBC count is trending upwards without fever, which may indicate ongoing sepsis. This can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Hypoxia: The patient is on nasal cannula oxygen and has a history of intubation for airway protection. She may be at risk for hypoxia, especially if her oxygen saturation levels drop.
4. Altered mental status: The patient has a history of altered mental status and is currently lethargic with low energy. This may be related to her infections, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
5. Hypotension: The patient is on low-dose pressors and has a history of hypotension. She may be at risk for further hypotension and organ failure.
6. ESRD on HD: The patient has ESRD on HD and may require further dialysis to manage her electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
7. Hepatitis B: The patient has HBV and is on entecavir and tenofovir. She may be at risk for liver damage and failure if her HBV infection is not well-controlled.
8. Abdominal wound: The patient has an abdominal wound that requires ongoing care and management. She may be at risk for wound infection and dehiscence.
9. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient has a history of portal venous and RIJ clots. She may be at risk for further clotting and embolism.
10. Anemia: The patient has anemia and may require further transfusions to manage her hematocrit levels.

In summary, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including disseminated fungal infection, sepsis, hypoxia, altered mental status, hypotension, ESRD on HD, hepatitis B, abdominal wound, portal venous and RIJ clots, and anemia. Close monitoring and management of these conditions are essential to prevent further complications and ensure the patient's overall well-being.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, ESRD on HD, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement with abdominal abscess requiring debridement. She has a history of HBV, autoimmune cholangiopathy, and C. diff infection.

The patient was successfully extubated yesterday and has been on low-dose pressors for septic physiology. She has been experiencing pain in the right lower extremity and has received two boluses of Fentanyl. Her current medications include micafungin, PO vancomycin, and flagyl for C. diff coverage.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C, heart rate of 67 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/49 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 27 breaths per minute, and her SpO2 is 96%. Her abdomen is soft and non-tender, with bowel sounds present.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 22.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 6.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 290 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 23.0 mg/dL
* Sodium: 136 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mmol/L
* Chloride: 102 mmol/L
* Carbon dioxide: 23.0 mmol/L
* Lactic acid: 1.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.1 g/dL
* LDH: 254 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.9 mg/dL

The patient's cultures show:

* BCx [**4-11**], [**4-13**], [**4-14**] positive for Candida albicans
* Pleural fluid [**4-14**]: negative on cultures
* PICC line tip [**4-15**]: negative on cultures
* LIJ line tip [**4-16**]: positive for PND

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue micafungin and C. diff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl
* F/u cultures
* Hold all TPN for now
* Plan for TEE tomorrow
* Call TEE fellow to confirm
* Continue to treat sepsis with low-dose pressors
* Wean pressors as tolerated
* Plan for CVVH/HD today with placement of temp HD catheter today
* Heparin on hold this AM in preparation for procedure
* Renal recs appreciated
* Plan for temp line placement and CVVH/HD today
* Continue entecavir and tenofovir
* Continue ursodiol
* Continue to follow synthetic function tests
* Liver recs appreciated
* Continue local care, wound vac
* Plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
* Continue insulin
* Will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
* Continue to follow daily Hct and transfuse for Hct > 21

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Candidemia and sepsis can lead to further complications such as organ failure, disseminated candidiasis, and mortality.
* C. diff infection can lead to further complications such as diarrhea, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
* Hypotension can lead to further complications such as organ failure, hypovolemic shock, and mortality.
* Leukocytosis can lead to further complications such as sepsis, organ failure, and mortality.
* Abdominal wound can lead to further complications such as infection, abscess, and fistula.
* Portal venous and RIJ clots can lead to further complications such as pulmonary embolism, stroke, and death.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications due to her underlying medical conditions and current treatment. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia readmitted with C. difficile colitis and found to have new candidemia with Candida albicans.

The patient has been on invasive ventilation and was successfully extubated around noon on [**4-17**]. She remains on micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl. The patient requires HD today, and a temporary HD line will be placed by the renal fellow tomorrow.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3C (97.4F), heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 110/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Her physical examination is limited due to her critical condition.

Laboratory results show an increase in white blood cell count, with a peak of 27.2 K/uL. Her platelet count has decreased to 415 K/uL, and her creatinine level is 3.6 mg/dL. Her liver function tests are abnormal, with an albumin level of 2.1 g/dL and a lactate dehydrogenase level of 254 IU/L.

The patient has multiple medical conditions, including candidemia, sepsis, C. difficile colitis, ESRD on HD, and autoimmune cholangiopathy. She is also at risk for hypoxia, altered mental status, hypotension, and portal venous and RIJ clots.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's WBC count is trending upwards, and she has not had a fever in recent days, which may indicate a disseminated fungal infection.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology requires low-dose pressors, and she may be at risk for further deterioration.
3. Candidemia: The patient's candidemia is likely related to her TPN, and she may require continued treatment with micafungin.
4. C. difficile colitis: The patient's C. difficile colitis may worsen if not properly treated.
5. ESRD on HD: The patient's ESRD on HD may require adjustments to her treatment regimen.
6. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient's autoimmune cholangiopathy may require further treatment and monitoring.
7. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient's portal venous and RIJ clots may require further treatment and monitoring.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical conditions, and her care requires close monitoring and management of her various comorbidities.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, who was successfully extubated yesterday and is currently on low-dose pressors. The patient has a complex medical history, including ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement and abdominal abscess.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.3C, HR 67 bpm, BP 110/49 mmHg, RR 27 inspirations per minute, SpO2 96%.
* Respiratory support: Nasal cannula with 40% FiO2.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Patient is on low-dose pressors and has a central venous catheter (CVC) in place.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received 1,376 mL of IV fluids and has a total output of 1,600 mL, resulting in a negative fluid balance of 224 mL.
* Laboratory results: The patient's WBC count is trending upwards, and her platelet count is 415 K/L. Her creatinine level is 3.6 mg/dL, and her glucose level is 116 mg/dL.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Candidemia with Aspergillus albicans, which is likely related to TPN and may have seeded her heart valves.
* C. difficile colitis, which is being treated with PO vancomycin and metronidazole.
* ESRD on HD, which may require CVVH in the future.
* Hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, and recent prednisone taper.
* Abdominal wound with wound vac, which is being managed by plastic surgery.
* Portal venous and RIJ clots, which are being treated with heparin gtt.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis and candidemia-related organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and respiratory failure.
* C. difficile colitis-related complications, such as perforation or abscess formation.
* Heart valve damage or vegetation formation related to candidemia.
* Hemorrhagic complications related to anticoagulation therapy.
* Wound complications, such as infection or dehiscence, related to the abdominal wound.
* Fluid overload or electrolyte imbalance related to IV fluids and medications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing micafungin and cdiff tx with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
* F/u cultures and blood work.
* Holding all TPN for now.
* Plan for TEE tomorrow to r/o vegetations.
* Continue CIS.
* Trial SBT again today for 30-60 minutes to see whether can trial extubation today.
* Favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or aspiration.
* Continue to hold narcotics.
* Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently.
* Treat infection as above.
* Plan for CVVH/HD today with placement of temp HD catheter today.
* Heparin on hold this AM in preparation.
* Nutrition: Consider Dophoff placement vs re-evaluate ability to take POs (likely will not be enough intake).
* No steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues.
* Continue entecavir and tenofovir.
* Continue ursodiol.
* Continue to follow synthetic function tests.
* Liver recs appreciated.
* Plastic surgery following, recs appreciated.
* Continue local care, wound vac.
* On heparin gtt, holding for AM, resume after procedure.
* Continue insulin.
* Will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI.
* Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21.

   Assessment and Plan
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis transferred back to the MICU with altered mental
   status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Lines re-changed yesterday [**4-16**]. Patient
   had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d. If
   seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess formation 3 week course would
   have likely been inadequate. Left thigh fluid collection previously
   drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from thigh NGTD.  She had no more
   fevers overnight but  is still very dependent on pressors. WBC still
   elevated at 23 ( has been ranging  22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage
   negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.  She has clean eye exam
   with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all
   old lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - ID following, discuss regarding taking off antibacterials
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant pseudomonas)
   but talk to ID regarding whether needs these, IV vanco and PO vanco
   given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Mental
   status improved today.
   - Trial SBT again today for 30-60min to see whether can trial
   extubation today
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration.
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Still intubated for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low dose Levophed but unable
   to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia. The patient has been transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status and found to have candidemia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 36.3C, Tcurrent 36C, HR 67 bpm, BP 110/49 mmHg, RR 27 inspirations per minute, SpO2 96%.
* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation stopped, currently on nasal cannula with CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 40%, PEEP 0 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular: Dependent on pressors, suspecting sepsis, and potentially fluid-overloaded.
* Neurological: Altered mental status, improved today, with a history of CVA and meropenem treatment.
* Abdominal: Wound vac changed, ABD CT unchanged.
* Hepatic: Hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, and recent prednisone taper.
* Renal: ESRD on HD, removed HD line, and sending for culture.
* Hematological: Leukocytosis, WBCs in the range of 22-26.
* Infectious disease: Candidemia, likely line-related, and possibly disseminated fungal infection.
* Laboratory results: Elevated WBC count, elevated CRP, and abnormal liver function tests.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Disseminated fungal infection
* Sepsis
* Candidemia
* C.difficile colitis
* Hepatitis B reactivation
* Autoimmune cholangiopathy
* Renal failure
* Hemorrhagic complications
* Neurological sequelae
* Cardiovascular instability
* Respiratory failure
* Abdominal wound complications
* Portal venous and RIJ clots

The plan is to:

* Continue micafungin and additional Ambisome for candidemia
* Hold all TPN for now
* Remove old lines and re-site new lines for fresh access
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and disseminated fungal infection
* Wean sedation as tolerated
* Consider neuro c/s
* Wean pressors as tolerated
* Continue local care and wound vac for abdominal wound
* Follow synthetic function tests for liver function
* Continue entecavir and tenofovir for Hepatitis B
* Continue ursodiol for autoimmune cholangiopathy
* Follow lytes daily for ESRD on HD
* Continue insulin for DM
* Maintain active T+S and transfuse for Hct>21 for anemia.

Summary:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), who has recently developed candidemia and is currently being treated in the intensive care unit (ICU). She has a prolonged hospital stay with an abdominal wound infection, and has also been diagnosed with Clostridium difficile (CDif) infection. The patient is extubated and able to breathe spontaneously with 2L of oxygen, but still requires mild levophed support. She has mild tachypnea and tachycardia, and is experiencing mild hypoxemia.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Her liver function tests are abnormal, and she has elevated levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). She is also experiencing altered mental status, which may be related to uremia and hepatic encephalopathy.

The patient's plan includes continued treatment for candidemia, surveillance cultures, and consideration of TEE. She will also undergo HD and CVVH, and will have her abdominal wound monitored. Additionally, she will receive antivirals and antibiotics as needed.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's candidemia and CDif infections may lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and tachypnea may lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's tachycardia and hypoxemia may increase her risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and possible AKI may worsen her renal function, leading to further complications.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's abnormal liver function tests and elevated LDH levels may indicate hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status and potentially lead to coma.
6. Meningitis: The patient's altered mental status may be related to meningitis, which can be caused by the Candida species.
7. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal wound infection and possible necrosis may lead to abdominal compartment syndrome, which can cause respiratory and circulatory compromise.
8. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's prolonged hospital stay and immobility may increase her risk of DVT, which can cause pulmonary embolism and death.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's condition to prevent further deterioration and improve her chances of survival.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 48-year-old female with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD) who has been hospitalized for a prolonged period due to an abdominal wound infection. She has recently developed CDiff and candidemia, and is currently being treated with various medications.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 35.6C (96F)
* Heart rate: 66 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 109/48 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Anxious and facial edema
* Scleral icterus
* Diminished radial and digital pulses in both arms and legs
* Soft and tender abdomen with mild ttp
* Right lower extremity edema (1+) and left lower extremity edema (1+)
* Muscle wasting
* Warm skin
* Attentive and follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, and has purposeful movement with decreased tone

Laboratory results show:

* WBC: 22.2-27.2 K/uL
* Hct: 23.0-23.0%
* Plt: 290-415 K/uL
* Cr: 2.8-3.6 mg/dL
* TCO2: 19-24 mmol/L
* Glucose: 63-116 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 24.8/59.8/2.4, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 34/0.21/0.21, ALT/AST: 9/36, Alk Phos/T Bili: 189/10.4, Differential-Neuts: 81.0%, Band: 0.0%, Lymph: 13.0%, Mono: 3.0%, Eos: 1.0%, Lactic Acid: 1.6 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.1 g/dL, LDH: 254 IU/L, Ca++: 7.7 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL, PO4: 5.9 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's candidemia and CDiff, there is a high risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and increased dyspnea with turns may indicate respiratory failure, which can be exacerbated by her underlying lung disease.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's diminished radial and digital pulses may indicate cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and recent HD may indicate ongoing renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and other complications.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status and elevated liver enzymes may indicate hepatic encephalopathy, which can lead to further neurological deterioration.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal wound infection and recent prolonged hospital stay may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and potential aspiration event may indicate neurological complications, such as stroke or intracranial hemorrhage.

In conclusion, this patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to manage her multiple medical complications.

   - guiac stools, monitor closely for any evidence of bleeding
   - hodling heparin for now
   - check q6h hcts
   - transfuse hct>25
   - continue PPI
   - follow up final CT abdomen read

   She has not had any positive cultures since transfer to the ICU.
   Suspect related to lines (PICC and or old HD catheter) in setting of
   TPN. These have now been removed. Opthal eval without evidence of eye
   involvement.
   - Continue micafungin pending fluc sensitivities, pending today
   - F/u cultures and CIS
   - Await TEE
   - Favor reexamining thigh fluid collection as might have been seeded
   since last tap and would represent reservoir for recurrence
   # C diff colitis
   Toxin assays negative here.
   - Would continue PO vanc (day#1=[**4-1**]) and flagyl (day #1=[**4-5**]) for 10d
   post end of broad spectrum antibiotics. Will discuss whether flagyl
   required with ID team.
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] septic etiology. She appears
   intravascularly volume overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low
   dose Levophed but unable to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed
